TEXT: The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national , who was born in DATE and lives in GPE . He was represented before the Court by Mr PERSON , a lawyer practising in GPE . The respondent Government were represented by PERSON , ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

The applicant , who is of NORP origin , visited GPE for the first time as a tourist DATE and DATE in order to see his sister , living in GPE . He then entered into a relationship with PERSON , a NORP citizen and a friend of his sister 's . On DATE he arrived in GPE for the second time . He stayed with PERSON and the couple married on DATE .

On DATE the applicant applied for a residence permit on the basis of the link to his wife . He stated that he had CARDINAL children in GPE , a boy named PERSON , born on DATE , and a girl named PERSON , born on DATE . Apparently , the children have different mothers . At an interview with the immigration authorities , the applicant stated that he was born and raised in the city of GPE , GPE , and that he had CARDINAL brothers and QUANTITY sisters all of whom , except the sister in GPE , lived in GPE . His CARDINAL children were living with their paternal grandmother in PERSON . He intended to bring them to GPE in the future .

On DATE the applicant was granted a temporary residence permit , which was later renewed several times . At interviews held in connection with these renewals , the applicant stated that he kept in contact with his children in GPE through telephone calls and letters and that he sent them money . As to where the children were living , the information given by the applicant varied . In DATE he asserted that PERSON lived with his maternal grandmother and PERSON with her mother and paternal grandmother . In DATE he stated that they both lived with their paternal grandmother . In DATE he claimed that PERSON lived with his maternal grandmother and PERSON with her mother .

On DATE a son , PERSON , was born to the applicant and PERSON On DATE the applicant was granted a permanent residence permit in GPE on account of his family ties . He acquired NORP citizenship on DATE .

On DATE applications for residence permits in GPE were submitted to ORG in GPE concerning the applicant 's mother , PERSON and PERSON . Asked about the applications , the applicant stated , in DATE , that he was PERSON 's legal guardian , although the guardianship had not been established by a court . The girl had lived with her mother until DATE , when she had moved in with her paternal grandmother as her mother had married and could not take care of PERSON for financial reasons . The applicant had not seen PERSON since leaving GPE but had spoken to her on the telephone . He had , however , lived with her in DATE , DATE and DATE . At an interview with ORG ( ORG invandrarverk ) in DATE , the applicant asserted that he had never lived with PERSON 's mother , nor had he lived permanently with PERSON and her CARDINAL - brother PERSON . However , the children had visited him and his mother for shorter periods of time while he was still in GPE . The applicant also stated that PERSON had lived with her mother until DATE when her mother had married and handed over PERSON to her paternal grandmother .

On DATE ORG rejected the applications . In regard to PERSON , the ORG referred to the applicant 's statement that she had lived with her mother until DATE when the mother had married and handed over her to the applicant 's mother . Concluding that the daughter had never been living with the applicant , ORG found that she could not be granted residence permits pursuant to chapter CARDINAL , section CARDINAL , subsection CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW ( Utlänningslagen , CARDINAL ) .

The applicant appealed against the decision . He appended an affidavit from ORG 's mother dated DATE in which she stated that PERSON had been living with her paternal grandmother since DATE , as she was unemployed and therefore unable to take care of her daughter herself .
On DATE ORG ( Utlänningsnämnden ) upheld ORG decision .

On DATE new applications for residence permits were submitted to ORG in GPE on behalf of PERSON and PERSON . From the documents appended it transpired that the applicant 's mother had died on DATE and that the applicant was in GPE for the funeral and to sort out certain issues that had emerged as a result of her death .

On DATE the second applications were rejected by ORG ( ORG ; previously ORG ) . ORG concluded that the children had never been living with the applicant and could not therefore be granted residence permits in GPE .

In an appeal of CARDINAL DATE , it was stated that PERSON was DATE when the applicant left GPE , which explained why the applicant had never lived with her . PERSON had lived alternately with his mother and father .
The appeal was rejected by ORG on DATE .

Third applications for residence permits for the children were lodged with ORG on DATE . There it was claimed that the previous decisions of the immigration authorities had been based on a misunderstanding . The applicant had had , it was stated , very close contact with the children while he was living in GPE . PERSON had lived with his mother at her parents ' home but the applicant had still maintained close contact with him . PERSON 's mother and the applicant had lived together for DATE after PERSON had been born until he went to GPE for the first time . When he had returned to GPE he had stayed with his mother and PERSON . PERSON had been living in CARDINAL of the neighbouring houses with her mother .
On DATE ORG rejected the applications , finding that the new claim concerning PERSON was not credible as the applicant previously had asserted that he had never cohabited with PERSON 's mother .

In an appeal it was submitted that the applicant had visited GPE DATE and DATE to commemorate the first anniversary of his mother 's death and that his son PERSON had been with him on the visit . It was further stated that PERSON and PERSON were at that time staying with their aunt , PERSON , one of the applicant 's sisters , in GPE and that the applicant was paying for their school fees and living expenses . An additional submission of DATE contained information that FAC was going to move with her family to GPE for studies in DATE , leaving the applicant 's children in GPE .

On DATE ORG rejected the appeal . Concerning PERSON , the ORG upheld the assessment of ORG . With regard to PERSON it was noted that he had reached the age of DATE and that he had never been a member of the same household as his father .

A fourth application for a residence permit for PERSON was lodged on DATE with ORG in GPE . Appended to the application was , inter alia , a copy of PERSON 's passports which included the names of CARDINAL of her aunts , including PERSON , to be contacted in the event of accident or death . It was further stated in the application that PERSON was currently living with a good friend of ORG , who is apparently the director of ORG in GPE .
On DATE ORG rejected the fourth application , stating that , apart from the fact that PERSON was no longer living with her aunt , no new circumstances had emerged .

In an appeal to ORG , PERSON 's counsel stated the following . During DATE after her birth , the daughter had been taken care of by her mother . Thereafter , she had lived with her father – the applicant – and her paternal grandparents , until her father left for GPE in DATE . It was therefore not correct that she had never lived with her father . That conclusion was based on incomplete information previously given by the applicant . It was further claimed that the woman who was at the time taking care of PERSON had accepted this responsibility on the condition that it would be a temporary measure and had contacted the applicant to inform him that she was going to travel abroad . PERSON therefore no longer had any relative or other person who could take care of her .

By a decision of CARDINAL DATE ORG rejected the appeal . It noted that the information on whether the applicant and PERSON had ever lived together had been changed on several occasions . In DATE , during the investigation relating to the first application , the applicant had stated that he had never lived together with his daughter . In submissions of DATE , PERSON 's counsel had stated that the she was DATE when the applicant left GPE and that they had thus not lived together . In further submissions of DATE , the counsel had stated that the applicant had lived with PERSON 's mother for DATE after PERSON 's birth and had then left the country . Having regard to the contradictory statements , ORG concluded that it had not been shown that PERSON had ever lived with the applicant .
On DATE the applicant and PERSON divorced .

The basic provisions concerning the right of aliens to enter and remain in GPE are found in LAW . LAW , section CARDINAL , subsection CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of the LAW provides that a residence permit may be given to an alien who is below the age of DATE and unmarried and who is or has been living at home with a parent who is resident in GPE or who has been granted a permit to reside in GPE .
